. 
It is famous for its huge São João (St. John's) celebrations in June. The city claims to have "the world's largest São João festivities".

value: 's airport is at accessible road distance.
- travel by bus (about 1 hour 30 minutes) is simple and comfortable.  I took the Caruaruense line and spent about R$20,00 each way.
, recognized by UNESCO as the largest center for figurative arts in the Americas.  Home to famous ceramist Mestre Vitalino and other artists
(Mestre Vitalino's House), open Monday through Saturday, 8AM-noon and 2PM-5PM; Sunday, 8AM-noon.  At Rua Mestre Vitalino, Alto do Moura
, open Tuesday through Saturday, 8AM-noon adn 2PM-5PM; Sunday, 8AM-1PM; at Rua São Sebastião, 181, Alto do Moura
name=Museu do Barro e da Cerâmica
content=Open Tuesday-Saturday, 8AM-5PM; Sunday, 8AM-1PM; at Espaço Cultural Tancredo Neves, bloco B. Praça Cel. José de Vasconcellos, 100, Centro; tel.: (81) 3701.1533

, a multifaceted cultural center with three key components: the City Museum (Museu Celso Galvão or Museu da Cidade), Memorial da Feira de Caruaru and an exhibit on popular folk art.  Open: Tuesday through Saturday, 8AM-5PM, at Rua Duque de Caxias, 1000, Centro; tel.: (81) 3721.1039

(Cordel Museum).  Museum dedicated to "Cordel" literature, a traditional pamphlet literature that was typical in Europe in the Middle Ages.  Northeastern Brazil is one of the few place in the world where this type of literature is still alive.
(Caruaru Street Market), Brazil's largest street market (handicrafts, lace and embroidery, leather products, traditional medicinal products, typical food, and almost anything you might want)

(Exchange-Exchange Street Market), a street market in which you can exchange the most strange goods, such as chickens for a watch, a parakeet for a bicycle, and the like.  Takes place on Wednesdays and Saturdays.
(Caroá Factory Museum), installed in what used to be Fábrica Caroá (1935-1978), Brazil's first factory to produce fiber products from the caroá plant.
, where all the action is.  Main attraction during São João (Saint John's) and São Pedro (Saint Peter's) festivals.  Lots of forró dancing going on with live music on three stages.
content=This page lists the schedule for the shows which are scheduled for this year.
(pottery art) from one of the 200 artists at the Alto do Moura neighborhood.
: Brazil's largest street market (handicrafts, lace and embroidery, leather products, traditional medicinal products, typical food, and almost anything you might want)
Caruaru has a very active commerce downtown.  It serves as a commercial and services hubs for an important part of the interior of Pernambuco.  Outside the city center, Caruaru Shopping
is a modern shopping mall with movie theaters and fast-food restaurants.

Local gastronomy includes several goat and bovine meat dishes, such as "buchada", "carne de sol", "chambarril" and "sarapatel".  Green beans and melted butter are also typical.
